docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Gruber, a professor at M.I.T., helped persuade the Obama administration that everyone should be required to get health insurance.

headline.seo: Jonathan Gruber, Health Care’s Mr. Mandate
headline.main: Academic Built Case for Mandate in Health Care Law

docs.abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor Jonathan Gruber helped persuade the Obama administration that everyone should be required to get health insurance; has spent decades modeling the intricacies of the health care system and is pessimistic over its future if the Supreme Court rules against the mandate in Obama's health care reform law.
docs.snippet: Jonathan Gruber, a professor at M.I.T., helped persuade the Obama administration that everyone should be required to get health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard two cases on the third and final day of arguments challenging President Obama’s 2010 health care law.

headline.main: Supreme Court Health Care Arguments: Day 3 Transcripts

docs.snippet: The Supreme Court heard two cases on the third and final day of arguments challenging President Obama’s 2010 health care law.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered several possible approaches if the individual mandate is removed from the law and also examined an expansion of Medicaid.

headline.seo: Supreme Court Debates Striking Down Whole Health Law
headline.main: On Day 3, Justices Weigh What-Ifs of Health Ruling
headline.print_headline: On Day 3, Justices Weigh What-Ifs of Health Ruling

docs.abstract: Supreme Court considers several possible approaches to Pres Obama's health care law if the individual mandate to purchase health insurance is removed and also examines an expansion of Medicaid; justices seem divided on both questions on the third day of arguments.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered several possible approaches if the individual mandate is removed from the law and also examined an expansion of Medicaid.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: -The owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where a worker died after falling into a mixing machine has been arrested on charges of underpaying employees, falsifying business records and violating workers' compensation and unemployment insurance laws, the authorities said on Wednesday. -The owner, Erasmo Ponce, faces 26 felony counts and 23 misdemeanor counts, according to a complaint filed in Brooklyn Criminal Court by Eric T. Schneiderman, the state's attorney general. Mr. Ponce surrendered to the authorities on Tuesday and was arraigned and released without bail, his lawyer said.

headline.main: Charges for Owner of Tortilla Factory Where Worker Died

docs.abstract: Erasmo Ponce, owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where worker Juan Baten died in 2011 after falling into a mixer, has been arrested on charges of underpaying employees, falsifying business records and violating workers' compensation and unemployment insurance laws; Ponce faces 26 felony counts and 23 misdemeanor counts according to complaint filed in Brooklyn Criminal Court by the New York State attorney general's office. (M)
